RelationshipElement.name: Context Group - Context
RelationshipElement.description: A 1-to-n relationship between the parent and its children, respectively.

RelationshipElement.name: Bonded To
RelationshipElement.description: Implements a bonded to for contexts

RelationshipElement.name: Arbitrarily separated from
RelationshipElement.description: When two or more context codes have been assigned to what is ultimately determined to be the same context

RelationshipElement.name: Broadly contemporary with
RelationshipElement.description: Contexts suspected to be contemporary but no direct physical relationship or evidence (i.e. adjacent buildings)

RelationshipElement.name: EarlierLater

Context.desc: The physical result of any single action whether it leaves a positive or negative record within the stratigraphic sequence. (MoLAS 1994)

Context_ID.desc: Every archaeological context (negative element (cut), deposit, structure, skeleton, artefact cluster) is given a unique 3 or 4 letter context code. Each trench is designated with a separate letter which starts the code, so it is immediately obvious to which trench a context belongs. For example context HAA belongs to Trench H, context MQP to Trench M etc. The contexts are labelled consecutively in alphabetical order using the letters following the trench letter. For Trench H the first context would be HAA, the second HAB, the third HAB and so on. In addition sets of letters can denote parts of trenches, buildings etc. E.g. HFs might denote contexts from a specific building. Burial context codes begin with the letter Z, followed by the trench letter. Hence burial ZHA is the first burial context from trench H. Check with the trench supervisor who will assign the context code from the central register.

Context_Name.desc: Enter a brief, clear name for the Context eg 'House A - west wall'

Grid_X.desc: The X coordinate on the SW corner of the context.

Grid_Y.desc: The Y coordinate on the SW corner of the context.

Location_Note.desc: Record the approximate location in the excavation area, for example: centre of Area A; NW corner area A. Also include, where relevant, the position in relation to other archaeological contexts or features e.g. between walls x and y.

Date_Opened.desc: Date on which the Context was first excavated. This will automatically be set to the date on which the context is recorded but can be edited using the keyboard.

Excavators.desc: Initials of the excavators that have worked on the context.

Excavation_Method.desc: Enter details here about the method of archaeological excavation.

opts.opt: Other Excavated by another method. Add details in Annotation field.

Horizon_Boundary.desc: Describe the boundary between this and the next context.

opts.opt: DoubtfulYou are uncertain of whether you accurately excavated a boundary between deposits
AmbiguousYou are uncertain as to whether there was a boundary between contexts.
MergingThere is a distinction between the excavated context and earlier context(s) but the excavated contexts and the earlier contexts grade into each other
ClearThe boundary with the earlier context(s) was very clearly defined during excavation.
ArbitrarySpitThere is no meaningful boundary with an earlier context. The boundary has been artificially created by the excavation process.

Contamination.desc: The extent to which the context has been contaminated.

opts.opt: Contaminated Contaminated by later material eg by unidentified cut at time of initial excavation by large scale animal or root activity which were not isolated by excavation by excavation processes some annoying person mixed the material or stuff fell into deposit from the section.

Possibly Contaminated At Boncuklu as at many sites there is significant animal activity represented by burrows. We aim to remove most animal burrow fill. This is easier in contexts with clear and compact sediment characteristics like plaster floors walls building fills more difficult in loose middens. In one sense at Boncuklu as at many sites every context is possibly contaminated but there would be little point in indicating that since it is something we generally understand. Therefore this option is to be used to indicate those situations where one may have tried to remove animal introduced or other contamination but are unsure this has been successful and there is a likely but not definitive chance of some later contamination beyond. This option also applies where there may have been later cuts not recognised but we are not sure.

High likelihood high amount derived It is very likely that significant amounts of earlier artifact and ecofact material has become incorporated in the deposit. For example; is this context a mud brick wall or other structure or building or structural debris or a deposit which has seen the redeposition of material excavated from cuts. These are all situations in which earlier material is likely to have been dug up and re-used (in the mud brick) or re-deposited (when digging out pits).
Low likelihood low amount derived You think there is little chance that very much earlier material has made it's way into this deposit.

Primary deposit You are very sure that the deposit and all finds therein directly relate to activity within a specific period of time and there is thus minimal amounts of derived material and no contamination.

Context_Type.desc: Describe the context type by selecting an icon as defined below. When you have selected a context type you can proceed to open the "Fill in context type details" page. Note this page will not open unless you have selected a context type.

opts.opt: Negative Element Any Context which represents the removal of earlier deposit and thus forms a negative interface (cut) with another context, such as a cut for a pit, burial, ditch, wall foundation or robber trench.
Deposit Any Context with deposited sediment and soil, such as floor layers, pit and grave fills, hearth fills and natural sediments.
Structure Any Context consisting of deliberately constructed structural element, independent of a Negative Element (i.e. cut, such as a wall or a hearth).

Plans.desc: Reference numbers to plans or drawings of this Context.

Section_Numbers.desc: Reference numbers to section drawings of this Context

Date_Closed.desc: The date excavation of the Context ended and it was closed. Press the 'Add Date Closed' button to insert today's date.

Highest_Level.desc: The highest elevation or 'starting level' recorded for that context relative to the site grid.

Lowest_Level.desc: The lowest elevation recorded for that context relative to the site grid.

Volume.desc: Estimate the volume of the context in litres. All soil will be collected in buckets of a known volume. A tally should be kept of buckets produced from a context and the total volume calculated using that tally.

Cut_Your_Interpretation.desc: Your interpretation of the likely function of the Context using standardised definitions.

opts.opt: Other Function not elsewhere described. Provide details in Annotation field.

Shape_of_Cut.desc: Describe the shape of the negative element/cut viewed from above.

opts.opt: Linear Straight sided but not square or rectangular.
Rectangular Two sides longer than the other.

Shape_of_Cut_-_Note.desc: Additional notes about the shape of the cut.

Shape_of_Corners.desc: Describe the shape of any visible corners of the negative element/cut.

Break_of_Slope_-_Top.desc: The degree with which the top surface of the edge of the cut breaks into the sides.

opts.opt: Gradual Some rounding to the top.
Not perceptible Well-rounded; there is no perceptible difference between the sides of the cut and the surface into which it protrudes.
Sharp Clear sharp slope, almost right-angled.
Shallow Gentle slope less than 45 degrees.

Sides_of_Cut.desc: Describe the shape of the cut as seen in cross section.

Shape_of_Base.desc: The shape of the base of the cut in profile.

Cut_Function.desc: Comment in more specific detail on your understanding of the reasons for the shape and nature of the cut.

Orientation.desc: Orientation of linear cuts eg N-S.

Inclination_of_axis.desc: Inclination of the axis of post- and stakeholes.

Structure_Your_Interpretation.desc: Your interpretation of the likely function of the structure.

opts.opt: Other Function not elsewhere described. Provide details in Annotation field.

Structural_Components.desc: Primary components of structure or feature eg dry-pressed brick rough-hewn stone.

opts.opt:
Brick Fired or sun-dried clay block used in masonry construction. Dry-pressed Dry pressed brick Glazed brick
Sandstock Hand-made colonial bricks
Earth Compact earthen wall or floor.

Stone Worked or unworked stone used in masonry walls. Ashlar Finely dressed stone with flat face. Other
Roughly-hewn Roughly cut stone: shows some sign of shaping. Rubble Stone fragments with few signs of shaping
Timber Timber uprights or other elements for a wall or fence. Beam Timber beam or support. Plank Timber plank for flooring or panelling. Post Round or square timber post.

Component_Finish.desc: How have the material types been prepared (i.e dressed stones polished/smoothed/painted plaster surface).

Bonding.desc: Additional details of the bonding/packing material.

opts.opt: Mortar Paste used to bind masonry blocks together. Cement mortar Cement based mortar. Lime-shell mortar Sandy mortar with lime and burnt shell inclusion.
Unmortared No visible bonding material ie unmortared.

Bonding_Details.desc: What has been used to bind the major elements together? Is there mud mortar in a wall, or chinking stones?

Distinguishing_Marks.desc: Describe and distinguishing marks on the bricks or stone, such as makers marks, score marks etc.

Number_Courses.desc: The number of vertical layers of structural elements such as bricks.

Set_In_Cut.desc: Give the cut context code if relevant. If not set in cut then put 'NA'.

Structure_Shape.desc: The shape of the structural element, in plan.

opts.opt: Linear Straight sided but not square or rectangular.
Rectangular Two sides longer than the other.
Rectangular With straight edges, upper and lower surfaces.
Boat shaped Concave surface opposite convex surface

Deposit_Your_Interpretation.desc: Your interpretation of the likely function of the context.

opts.opt: Indeterminate You are unable to make an assessment of possible function.
Packing Packing in a post hole for post material fulfilling a constructional purpose other than deliberate levelling deposits.
Makeup/Levelling Material laid down to level or raise an area for constructional purposes or other activities.
Dump Material probably dumped as a result of other activity e.g. material removed from cuts or other constructional or destructional activity.
Midden Distinct area of organic rubbish accumulation
Burial A fill or other deposit associated with a skeleton and forming part of a burial feature.
Structural Debris/Collapse Material derived from collapse of a wall, roof or other structure
Partly naturally derived A deposit partly or wholly accumulating through natural sedimentary processes, such as water or wind deposition.

Wholly naturally derived All of the deposit accumulating through the deposition of natural sediments through geomorphological processes eg wind borne sediments water-laid natural sediments material flaking from cave and rock shelter walls.
Erosional products Material deriving from the erosion of earlier archaeological sediments.
Artifact Cluster A distinct concentration of artifacts or ecofacts. Make sure you record its xyz coordinates centre and edges.
Ash/Charcoal A deposit consisting largely of carbonized/charred plant material and/or ash

Arbitrary This applies to artificial contexts excavated for excavational convenience eg section cleaning material whose precise provenience is unclear. Does not include arbitrary spits or spatial units deliberately excavated for finer control of horizontal and vert

Distinct floor contact To be used for material that directly reflects the use of a surface or floor - artefact material on the surface perhaps thin deposits of occupation material. These contexts will be gridded into spatial units for closer control of artifact distributions.
Animal/Plant Deposit derived from plant or animal activity
Other Function not elsewhere described. Provide details in Annotation field.

Soil_Compaction_Type.desc: Describe the compaction of the sediments in the Context.

opts.opt: Medium Compact Somewhere between loose and compact.
Concrete Rock hard resistant to trowelling.
Friable Deposit disintegrates into small particles under pressure.
Crumbly Deposit disintegrates into lumps under pressure.

Soil_Compaction_Description.desc: Description of the compaction of soil including changes throughout the deposit. Eg "Varies from loose to compact."

Soil_Particle_Sorting.desc: Assessment of the frequency with which particles of the same size occur.

opts.opt: Moderately sorted Particles are mostly the same size and evenly distributed but there are some larger particles.
Poorly sorted Particles are different sizes and unevenly distributed.
Very poorly sorted Particles are very different sizes and very unevenly distributed.
Well sorted Particles are roughly the same size and evenly distributed.

Soil_Texture.desc: The type of sediment, eg clay, silt, sand and loam. Use the Material Helper or a Soil Sediment diagram for assisance.

opts.opt: No Observation No Observation. Use the Texture helper to prefil this.
Sand A sand has a loose gritty feel and does not stick together. Individual sand grains can be seen or felt. (VDEPI 2009: AG0058)
Loamy Sand In a loamy sand particles barely stick together and a moulded piece of soil just holds its shape. (VDEPI 2009: AG0058)
Silty Clay Loam A silty clay loam is like a clay loam but silty as well and smooth to the touch. (VDEPI 2009: AG0058)

Clay Loam More easily moulded into a shape than a loam a clay loam rolls out to a thin ribbon between the palms while a loam will break-up. When dry a clay loam will form a lump but is not as tough to break as a clay.(VDEPI 2009: AG0058)
Sandy Clay Loam A sandy clay loam is like a clay loam but sand grains can be felt (and heard - see Sandy Loam) (VDEPI 2009: AG0058)

Silt Loam A silty loam is like a loam but has a smooth silky feel when a moist sample is pushed between the index finger and thumb. On drying a sample can form a hard lump but this may be broken by hand. (VDEPI 2009: AG0058)

Loam A loam breaks into crumbs but will tend to stick together. Sand grains cannot be felt in a moist sample which when squeezed will retain its shape when handled freely. Loams are usually soft to the feel. (VDEPI 2009: AG0058)

Sandy Loam A sandy loam sticks together more than a loamy sand but can be easily broken. Individual sand grains can be felt and heard if a wet sample is rubbed between the index finger and thumb and held close to the ear. (VDEPI 2009: AG0058)
Silty Clay A silty clay is like a clay but smoother. (VDEPI 2009: AG0058)

Clay Clays are tough and can be moulded into shapes when moist. Clays form a long flexible ribbon when rubbed between the palms and the ribbon can often be bent into a U shape without breaking. Clays dry into very hard clods. (VDEPI 2009: AG0058)
Sandy Clay A sandy clay is like a clay but sand grains can be felt (and heard - see Sandy Loam). (VDEPI 2009: AG0058)

Soil_Colour.desc: Broad colour description of the soil, eg 'mid greyish brown'.

Composition_Type.desc: Describe the structure of the Context sediment. The components making up the structure are added below as aggregates.

opts.opt: Heterogeneous Deposit with different mixed components which need to be described.
Laminated Laminated Deposit consists of lots of fine lenses of the same material. Compact laminated Deposit consists of a number of fine lenses of different materials.
Compact Laminated Deposit consists of a number of fine lenses of different materials

Deposit_Bedding.desc: Describes the base of the deposit

opts.opt: Uneven Mix of horizontal, oblique and undulating - make sure you describe this

Sterile.desc: Whether or not the deposit is sterile, ie contains no artefacts

Deposit_Inclusions.desc: Enter a brief description of inclusions (eg stone flecks artefacts).

Space.desc: Enter the space number, which may define an internal or external area in which the skeleton is located.

Building.desc: A building can comprise one or more internal spaces so enter the building number in which the skeleton is located.

Mid_X.desc: An appropriate mid-point on the skeleton under excavation should be recorded on the X / Y co-ordinates. This will locate the skeleton on the site grid system.

Mid_Y.desc: An appropriate mid-point on the skeleton under excavation should be recorded on the X / Y co-ordinates. This will locate the skeleton on the site grid system.

Skeleton_Dimensions.desc: Record the approximate extent of the skeletal remains (in meters or millimetres only) and the axis of measurement. Detailed dimensions can be taken from the plan.

Skeleton_Head.desc: Which way up the head faces and/or points

Skeleton_Body.desc: Describe the attitude of the body, whether it is extended, crouched, flexed, supine (front up), prone (face down) and the orientation.

Skeleton_Left_Arm.desc: Record whether left arm is straight or flexed, is along the side of the body, over the chest or on the pelvis, and the position of the hand.

Skeleton_Right_Arm.desc: Record whether right arm is straight or flexed, is along the side of the body, over the chest or on the pelvis, and the position of the hand.

Skeleton_Left_Leg.desc: Record whether the leg is straight or bent, crossed left over right or right over left and the position of the foot

Skeleton_Right_Leg.desc: Record whether the leg is straight or bent, crossed left over right or right over left and the position of the foot

Skeleton_Condition.desc: Describe the general condition of the skeleton and any comments on articulation. Any degeneration of bone in situ is important to record as well as accidental damage during excavation and lifting. Record disturbances through later activity or animal/root activity as well as damage due to stone pressure on the bones. It is important to note whether the patellae, hyoid, phalanges, basi-occipital etc are present or not, and their location, as this may give an indication of the state of the body at the time of interment.

Skeleton_Surface_Modifications.desc: Note any cut marks, evidence of stains and/or colour during the course of the excavation, burning, chewing marks, root activity etc.

Skeleton_Environment.desc: The physical environment at the time of excavation may affect the state of the bone therefore it is important to note the weather and conditions you are working in.

Skeleton_Days_Exposed.desc: It is important to excavate skeletal remains as quickly as possible as the state of the bone will change during exposure. Any conditional change should also be noted. Excavate as quickly as possible because the bones will degrade rapidly.

Site_Code.desc: Short code to signify the excavation site and often the year of excavation. Assigned automatically by the module.

SearchHelp.desc: This allows you to find any contexts that contain your search term or string in any field in a context record. Type in your term/string and press the "Search" button. Press "My Contexts" to return to the full list of contexts for this trench.

Context_Group_ID.desc: Feature number taken from the central register.

$2

Building.desc: Identify the building in which the feature is located.

Space.desc: Identify the space in which the feature is located if relevant.

Location_Note_CG.desc: Record where the feature is within a space / building/area if relevant and in particular its relationship to other features or key contexts.

CG_Context_Type.desc: Enter the type of feature you are describing.

opts.opt: Negative Element Any Context which forms a negative interface (cut) with another context, such as a cut for a pit, burial, ditch, wall foundation or robber trench.
Deposit Any Context with deposited sediment and soil, such as floor layers, pit and grave fills, hearth fills and natural sediments.
Structure Any Context consisting of deliberately constructed structures, independent of a Negative Element (i.e. cut, such as walls and hearths).
Wall A structured vertical barrier made from durable materials defining a space.
Floor A prepared surface, internal or external, including those made from plaster, earth etc.
Well A deep pit excavated to reach the water table.
Pit A large cut filled with sediment or other materials.
Room A discrete space within a house or other building.
Burial The cut, fill plus any associated structures relating to the deposition of human remains, including those remains, such as a skeleton.
Building A building is defined when several walls surround a discrete space
Surface A compacted horizontal layer, internal or external, on which activities took place.
Space A space is an area bounded by a structure of some kind, either external or internal, and can be for example a courtyard, room, ante-room etc.
PostholeA small pit cut to hold an upright post.
StakeholeCuts smaller than postholes, typically c. 1-5 cm diameter.
HearthA prepared structure in which a fire is set.
Stakehole row A row of cuts smaller than postholes, typically c. 1-5 cm diameter.
OtherFunction not elsewhere described. Provide details in Annotation field.

Component.desc: Describe the components which make up 10% or more of the deposit.

opts.opt: Small Stones Size up to 10 mm.
Tauf Mud building material including mortar.
Midden Organic debris e.g. bones carbonised material phytoliths etc
Mudbrick Fragments of mudbrick or whole mudbricks not part of a coherent structural element.
Ash White/grey fine material which may contain charcoal and other burnt plant material.
